Piastri has incredible race craft and instinct. 

He knows the car's limits and pushes it right to the cliff's edge without falling. 

He also seems to be highly aware of his surroundings (other drivers, walls, etc.) and takes up as much of the track as he can to gain speed but also limit overtake chances of other drivers. 

He is even aware of his own slipstream behind and constantly tries to break it whilst maintaining the best racing line himself, making the other drivers behind try to keep in the slipstream but also try to overtake him from a bad racing line. 

Really smart crafty racing.

Bearman is a great driver, and credit to him for being in the right place when two drivers DNF'd in the last two laps, allowing him to score points. However, let’s not create an obscure and almost irrelevant metric, like scoring points in his first two races with different teams. Who else in F1 history would have driven two different cars in their first two races? Probably only test drivers for sister teams like Ferrari or Red Bull, or in very rare cases, someone from the same engine supplier. No one was aiming for that kind of accomplishment—it's like Guinness making a category no one asked for, just to set a record.

I'd reckon the entertainment of this race would surpass all into the top 2% of all races ever since 1950. Just an absolute thriller.

It's a shame the broadcasting was subpar as usual today since there was about 8-10 laps prior to showing the lead fight where Leclerc was within 6-9 tenths behind at certain points in EACH of those 8-10 laps that they didn't show whatsoever (even a small pop-up screen in the bottom right corner as they sometimes do would suffice- just anything) but at least they showed the final 15-20 laps of them fighting it out.. It was just super frustrating watching live and wanting to know what was going on at the sharp end rather than seeing Verstappen trying to hold back Norris or seeing the 2 Williams (who are doing supremely well and do deserve air time) but if there's 0.5s gap between the lead- that HAS to be the focal point... My opinion to the crash: 
Racing incident with nobody really to blame as both drivers had only tiny margins to play with.

But if you had to blame somebody, it would have to be Sainz. If you watch the replay from above Perez drives straight and even steers a tiny bit to the left. He is far enough alongside that Sainz can't dictate Perez's racing line. So he had every right to stay in the middle of the road.
Sainz on the other hand creeps over to the left and doesn't drive straight on. You can see that again in the replay. 
But you also have to acknowledge that the track goes slightly left on that straight. Even with that in mind I feel like Sainz turned too much into Perez and had been granted enough room on the outside. 

Again these are very small margins and because of that I don't really think any driver is at fault.

I'm a stroll hater and a tsunoda diehard fan, but stroll clearly had the inside there and tsunoda turned into the corner way too early and ran into stroll. The absolute lack of race craft knowledge of current F1 fans is insane

For overtaking on the inside of a corner a driver must be given room if they satisfy the following conditions:

Have their front axle at least alongside the mirror of the other car no later than the apex of the corner
Be driven in a safe and controlled manner throughout the manoeuvre (which includes the entry, apex and exit)

I'm really amazed at how people can blame Sainz for this one. He was just defending his position, his move was 100% allowed by the rules and Pérez wasn't more than half a car's length next to the side of Sainz. 

+ why on Earth did Pérez not avoid the contact by turning left??? He had one and a half car width of space to avoid contact and he had the DRS anyway, he would've passed Sainz even by going left. 

This is just some absolutely shocking awareness from Pérez's side and that's purely dangerous for any driver racing next to him. Sainz was just defending his place by compromising Pérez's line, that's not illegal whatsoever. 100% on Pérez on that one.

And what's even more shocking is that, instead of going left and keep a podium to salvage his absolutely godawful season (istg even Kvyat did better back in the days), he preferred to play it reckless (I don't even think he was looking at Sainz at that point) and score a big bold 0 while his team's already struggling big time for points.
